Actinopolyspora saharensis is a species of actinobacteria that was isolated from a soil sample collected in the Sahara Desert in Algeria. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and halophilic bacterium, meaning it can thrive in high-salt environments.

The cells of Actinopolyspora saharensis are non-motile, and they form branched, septate hyphae during growth. The colony morphology on agar plates is typically chalky white in color. This species is able to tolerate a wide range of salt concentrations, with optimal growth occurring in the presence of 10-20% (w/v) NaCl.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Actinopolyspora saharensis belongs to the genus Actinopolyspora, which is a member of the family Thermomonosporaceae within the order Actinomycetales. The species is considered an extremophile, as it is adapted to survive and grow in the harsh, arid conditions of the Sahara Desert.

Further studies on the physiology, biochemical properties, and potential biotechnological applications of Actinopolyspora saharensis may provide insights into the adaptations of actinobacteria to thrive in hyper-arid, high-salinity environments.
